evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently reported during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as per hist_t2_interim data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: No credible evidence contradicts the presence of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, confirming its role as a root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including misaligned crew actions and failure to share critical information timely.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently reported during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as per hist_t2_interim data.

assumptions: Lack of warning from wingman and headset operator implies communication/coordination breakdown among crew.
The incident context and crew roles as described are representative of the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given and acknowledged during pushback, or if mechanical failure was confirmed as cause.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly indicates lack of warning from wingman and headset operator, showing communication breakdown; H1-H3 show communication channels and crew interactions consistent with coordination issues.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in extent and consistency of communication breakdown; no explicit reports of repeated or consistent communication failures.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including misaligned crew actions and failure to share critical information timely.

assumptions: Misaligned crew actions and failure to share critical information are inferred from lack of warnings and seat swap
No mechanical failure evidence present in provided data
defeaters: If evidence showed timely and effective communication among crew or clear procedural adherence
If mechanical faults were identified that better explain the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Discriminators favor communication breakdown over procedural deviation, marking deficiency, or mechanical failure.

assumptions: Assuming that absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator indicates communication breakdown.
Assuming that the described behaviors reflect the overall crew coordination state.
defeaters: If credible evidence showed effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if procedural deviations fully explained the event, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Communication and signaling issues are distinct from marking deficiencies.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations on 12-25 as recorded in hist_t2_interim.

The TRP and blast barrier locations and markings are as described and relevant to procedural compliance.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear communication failure or environmental factors causing the deviation, it would challenge the procedural deviation alignment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

H2 and H3 describe the trainee stopping and instructor taking over, consistent with procedural actions. H8 indicates communication signals were insufficient, supporting procedural deviation over communication breakdown. Thus, the procedural deviation aligns with key features in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations.

node.statement: The identified environmental or marking deficiency aligns with the key features and characteristics expected for such deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model within the specified historical period.

The tug instructor's assessment in H8 accurately reflects the signaling limitations rather than marking deficiencies.

The lack of warning signals from wingman or headset operator is due to procedural or situational factors, not communication channel absence.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment failure or lack of established communication protocols, this would change the assessment.
If the headset operator or wingman had been out of communication range or unavailable, the conclusion would differ.

children_spec.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather, lighting) was available at the time of the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if weather reports, lighting conditions, and other environmental data were recorded and accessible during the incident timeframe

children_spec.statement: Marking information (e.g., signage, runway markings) was present and accessible to the flight crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify presence and visibility of relevant markings through inspection reports, photographs, or crew statements

children_spec.statement: Communication systems providing environmental or marking information were operational and available
children_spec.test_procedure: Review communication logs and system status reports to confirm availability and functionality during the incident

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters in the context of Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25 during hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure is inferred from the aircraft moving beyond the TRP despite engine idle and no procedural errors clearly causing the event.
No direct evidence of communication breakdown or environmental deficiency causing the failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective procedural warnings or operator errors causing the event, this would reduce resistance to defeaters.
If mechanical faults were not confirmed or if communication breakdowns were primary causes.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H8 show the aircraft moved beyond the TRP despite engine idle and no effective warning signals, indicating mechanical/control failure was resistant to defeaters related to procedural deviations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from mechanical failure without fault codes or bench checks

node.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather, lighting) was available at the time of the incident

defeaters: If evidence showed poor visibility or absence of environmental markings at the time, or crew were unaware of the markings, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and visibility of the TRP environmental marking; H8 and H9 indicate that the crew were aware of the marking and its location, supporting that relevant environmental data was available at the time.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly supports availability of environmental data.

node.statement: Communication systems providing environmental or marking information were operational and available

defeaters: If evidence showed communication signals were clear and warnings were given by wingman or headset operator, the claim might be supported.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the TRP marking was present and visible, indicating environmental markings were available. However, H8 indicates communication signals were insufficient and no warnings were given, suggesting operational availability of communication systems was lacking, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication systems were fully operational despite marking visibility

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are physically present and installed in the aircraft
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft to verify the presence and installation of all mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from physical damage or wear that would prevent operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Perform a detailed physical inspection and maintenance records review to identify damage or wear

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are not obstructed or jammed, allowing free movement
children_spec.test_procedure: Conduct functional tests and physical checks to confirm no obstructions or jams exist

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to the control inputs
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections through inspection and functional testing

node.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform the pushback procedure

assumptions: Qualification and awareness imply availability of qualified personnel
No contradictory evidence on personnel availability present
defeaters: If evidence showed the trainee driver was unqualified or unaware of the TRP
If environmental or mechanical factors were documented as primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H9 directly states the trainee driver was qualified and aware of the TRP, supporting availability of qualified personnel for the pushback procedure. This supports the procedural deviation root over alternatives as per discriminator texts.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on communication or mechanical failure quality; assumptions on qualification based on training statements.
